// Write a programme to merge two strings
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
	var str1, str2 string

	fmt.Print("Enter String 1 : ")
	if _, err := fmt.Scan(&str1); err != nil {
		panic("Scan Error str1")
	}

	fmt.Print("Enter String 2 : ")
	if _, err := fmt.Scan(&str2); err != nil {
		panic("Scan Error str2")
	}

	mergedString := str1 + str2

	fmt.Printf("\nOutput : %s\n", mergedString)
}


// Write a programme to merge two strings
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

int main()
{
    /* Define a temporary variable */
    char mergedString[100], str1[50], str2[50];

    printf("Enter String 1 : ");
    scanf("%s", str1);
    printf("Enter String 2 : ");
    scanf("%s", str2);

    strcpy(mergedString, str1);
    strcat(mergedString, str2);

    /* Display the concatenated strings */
    printf("\nOutput : %s\n", mergedString);

    return 0;
}

// Write a programme to merge two strings
using System;

class MergeTwoStrings
{
    static void Main(string[] args)
    {
        try
        {
            // Initialisation
            string firstStr = string.Empty;
            string secondStr = string.Empty;

            // Read values from keyboard
            Console.Write("Input1 : ");
            firstStr = Console.ReadLine();

            Console.Write("Input2 : ");
            secondStr = Console.ReadLine();

            // Display output
            // Note: Use of string interpolation ($ operation) to concat/merge two variables
            Console.WriteLine($"Output : {firstStr}{secondStr}");
        }
        // Handle other exceptions
        catch (Exception ex)
        {
            Console
                .WriteLine($"Errors => {ex.Message}{Environment.NewLine}{
                    ex.StackTrace}");
        }
    }
}
